column5: @coinerrorguide @JocAPhotography They tend to work mature trees and so are high up‚Äîquite a few in DC, where they have lots of older, taller trees. Have seen them working a tree stump though, going after the carpenter ants. Amazing looking.
ESPN has been kinda mean with its coverage of the Australian Open, to see most of the matches I‚Äôd have to pay extra, plus their team isn‚Äôt even in Melbourne.
@JocAPhotography Interesting how impressionistic this appears
@LebergerDavid The coming demographic crisis may force adjustments to Social Security, etc., but with luck by then we'll all have a universal basic income, or similar
Australian Open: with no line judges, the courts look deserted
Maybe just me, but there's some weird ads on Twitter these days!
Sometimes the NYTimes is really annoying. Did they only just discover that old and overgrown cemeteries are a haven for wildlife? See today‚Äôs NYT
Maybe we‚Äôll look back on this period as one when the inmates had a good go at taking over the asylum. It‚Äôs one consequence of an information-rich world.
Birds coming to the feeder today are all fluffed up, it‚Äôs so cold, windy and snowy. I‚Äôve put out extra seed, peanuts and suet so they can stoke up.
Nothing like these World Cup matches, with the people roaring and singing
Guess I‚Äôm no longer a good soccer fan because I expect goals when what today‚Äôs players are trying to do is to keep the ball away from their opponents‚Äîforget scoring!
@DavidJarratt1 @MarketingLancs Lovely picture, David.
See that woman run!
It's almost inevitable that a worldwide channel of news and information with no discernible political POV would get taken over by a well-off capitalist hungry for a voice.
Not just beautiful, but extraordinarily so, these ships are a reminder of our ancestors' ability to design and build to a timeless standard https://t.co/sXpQroMdty
@clarkle01 I don‚Äôt know if this was a red tail, all I saw was a swirl of barred feathers and wings. As you know, most of these hawks migrate down through Michigan and cross Lake Erie to go south
@harpy128 Yes, like a flash. Doves here do rather over reproduce themselves, so I suppose that‚Äôs good for the hawks. I suspect that in the past farmers probably raised doves for food.
Nature red in tooth and claw moment early this morning when a hawk snatched a dove from my bird feeder. It was all over in a second for the poor dove, with only feathers left.
Voted this am. Easy, pleasant poll workers, busy, but not crowded. Thanks, Van Buren Twp.!

Mr Musk is following a long tradition of those with money, resources, & a point of view buying a media outlet to represent it. In the past, it might have been a newspaper, or a radio station. Now it's tv & social media. Tomorrow, maybe Alexa, or her AI successors.

A facet of human behavior that social media enhances and enables is a craving for attention. Now we have people who previously wouldn't have been listened to getting the media attention they crave. In future we have to learn to manage this better, as we have in the past.
I remember seeing this episode, of DeSantis bullying children. It's what I most remember about him.

Interesting to know what the Repub candidates for this fall's election who are denying the results of the 2020 election plan to do if they win? Especially if the opposing candidates and the voters call it a fake result. Sauce for the goose and all that.

Well done it again! Knocked myself out for a couple of days in a reaction to the Covid vaccination booster shot (4). I guess I (we, us) will have to get used to this reaction & plan a day(s) off for it.
Commentators on the Rudd-Alcaraz match (US Open) seem biased. Maybe Alcaraz reminds them of themselves as young players and their hopes & desires in those days

Remember being invited next door by our neighbors to watch Queen Elizabeth's coronation live on their new (b&w) television, the first on the street. One of the longest remote broadcasts at the time & a sense of a new era opening.
Go a little further than that--DC, with about the same population as Wyoming gets NO senators!
How the Roman military loved squares and right angles
I voted today, in person. Thanks to the primary election workers in Van Buren who made the experience straightforward and enjoyable!
Whenever change gets too complex, or too fast, there are always people who want to take a u-turn into the past. We‚Äôve got 4 of them on the Supreme Court right now

One of the jobs of a futurist is to identify not just the new cycles of change emerging, but also to note the inevitable ending of a cycle. In the US, with Dobbs, this is not the start of a new cycle of harassing women. It‚Äôs the final fanfare of an old one.
@Radmiddle Agreed

From the perspective of a futurist, the Supremes decision on Roe, as well as states‚Äô efforts to forbid everything they can think of reflects an era on its way out, not a new and growing social system.
The crowd at Wimbledon gets an end of evening bonus, mixed doubles with Venus Williams & Jamie Murray. Me too!

Are so many judges and lawyers essential to the future of democracy in the US? They tend to preserve the past. Perhaps what‚Äôs needed is a new kind of expert who can adapt our system to the future, and respect the changes in modern life.
@Radmiddle And they tend to create more misery than they think they are alleviating
You have to have the right kind of voice to be an on-air sports commentator. Caroline Wozniaki, much as I admire her, does not.
When you ban something that people want, they turn to crime to supply it. Surely that‚Äôs obvious, even to the Supremes
Unusual to hear David Brooks on PBS advocating that we look to the future of our governmental system. Rather than raking over the past, that is (Jan 6)
The US Senate seems to be useless.

Hard to see what the objectors, rally-ists, etc. envision as their desired future for the US. There are no policies, no platform. In any event, demography is against them, especially as they age & no one follows.
If you are a Civil War buff you can see bluebirds on the battlefields‚Äîtry Antietam or Gettysburg. They seem to like that open countryside.

What's the value of considering the long-term consequences of decisions? A futurist would say you should, it's critical. A US Supreme Court justice? Probably believes that's for others to worry about.

If you are the couple who arrives late to a big match at the French Open, the crowd, the players, the officials will all wait in silence until you've sat down. Got to be one of life's more embarrassing moments
Gov. Abbott blaming others. No surprise there. Wasn‚Äôt it him passing legislation to make gun ownership easier?
Republicans, governors in particular, are working really hard at being monsters. Could they maybe take a day or two off and just be normal, able to feel pain & the distress of others?
The all-male gang behind Gov. Abbott in his press conference on Uvalde maybe says more about who runs Texas than they should.
@Radmiddle @vintagemapstore Well, misfortune was many people‚Äôs lot in the Depression, & New York was always a tough town.
We seem to have acquired some Gilded Age judges.
@Radmiddle @vintagemapstore That‚Äôs fascinating, Tim. Did your family live on those lots?
There‚Äôs a couple of governors in the South who seem to want to harass and bully their citizens. Not sure why this makes them seem re-electable.
Smog bound city!
The ability of our established institutions to keep their processes and decisions secret has gone for good. Some of them may not have realized it yet.
The effort being put by many into holding their society back from change and the future is astonishing.

A consequence of a high-information society is the rush to take advantage of the information streams. I see this in the growing numbers of attention seekers, ‚Äúinfluencers,‚Äù ‚Äúconflict entrepreneurs,‚Äù (used to be known as rabble-rousers) self-styled experts, political ‚Äúvoices‚Äù etc.

@KarlSchroeder John Naughton at https://t.co/n8ohX3gCi3 relates Ashby‚Äôs law to our current  information overload as stressing the older systems trying to cope with it. In a way, authoritarianism does people a favor by limiting info. complexity. It may seem like a relief to some.

A low-coercion social system is likely also high-information, (See Friedman, NYT for the opposite) In thinking about the future, countries like the US have more information than we know what to do with, yet it‚Äôs probably also our shield against an authoritarian takeover.

Thomas L. Friedman's point in the NYT today that "high-coercion authoritarian systems are low-information systems," by necessity is important for futurists to think about, esp in crisis, such as war, or pandemic, when information flow is essential
Old bigfoot!
It would be indeed surprising if Finland and Sweden were not considering joining NATO after what Putin/Russia has done in Ukraine. He has clearly changed the future of Europe
Uncomfortable feeling of being an hour late for everything today

Looks like we have another crazy uncle in the attic. It‚Äôs time we developed some governmental systems that don‚Äôt cede power to one individual. It‚Äôs not like it is an unrecognized problem. This is the future folks!

Have to wonder if the attack on Ukraine has to do with a dictator being housebound and isolated during the pandemic? After all, unless there is a cabal, it's only one man pushing this unprovoked aggression.

ESPN is doing a pathetic job covering the AO (Australian Open) unless one is willing to pay extra. Considering how much already has to be paid to Xfiniti/Comcast-including costs for sports one doesn't ever watch, in these areas consumers have zero power

@StephaniePride Sorry to hear you felt ill, hope you are feeling better & have a terrific 2022!

A note to all those authors giving us their "predictions" for 2022 at this time of year. 1. The crystal ball is an ancient cliche, 2. Futurists don't do "predictions"--it's a sure way to be wrong about the future. Just tell us what you believe will change and _why_ you think so.
I may be the last to realize this, but if you are wearing a mask, your phone can't recognize your face. Duh! I suspect this may apply anywhere facial recognition is being used
Song sparrow?
Woof

The NYTimes is spending a lot of time and effort evaluating the best consumer goods these days. They might also consider looking at their own product, the jumpy, bumpy, delayed, flash, flash, blank screen whirly circle AGAIN iPad app. It blights my every morning.
Joe Manchin‚Äôs a dinosaur, funded by dinosaurs. It‚Äôs astonishing how one dinosaur, and his backers, can delay the future and hold back the adaptations we will have to make to survive it.

The FDA is maybe planning to authorize half-doses of Moderna as booster shots for Covid protection. Now they tell me!

Got my Moderna booster shot yesterday‚Äîno clear sailing this time tho‚Äô, feels like flu today, achy, shivery, nausea, sore, thirsty. Recommend you drink lots of water, liquids,  before and after if you plan to get this shot. Might help.

My weekend conclusion: Was watching a mystery in which the heroine never, ever, combs her hair. It‚Äôs in a long straggle, very distracting. So I‚Äôve concluded that another actor, a woman whose hair is immaculate, must be the murderer. A clue, right?

2/ Nominating is simple. In a nutshell, send Andy Hines an email (ahines@uh.edu) with your nomination. Include: Title; author; format; date; publisher; category; nominating member; why you think it‚Äôs important (no more than 300 words)

APF members: the July 31 deadline to nominate a "Most Significant Futures Work" is fast approaching. The ‚Äúwindow‚Äù for nominations is works published between January 1, 2019‚Äîpresent https://t.co/fwsZuVaGRw /1
